Headline.Para: Planes, Trains and Autos: Students Pour Into D.C. to Rally for Tougher Gun Laws; The student-led March for Our Lives rally aims to ride momentum for gun-control activism that began in February after the Parkland, Fla., school killings

LeadPara.Para: Young people from across the U.S. are piling into buses, cars and airplanes and heading to Washington, D.C., where they plan to gather by the tens of thousands on Saturday to demand stricter gun laws in America.

The student-led March for Our Lives rally aims to ride momentum for gun-control activism that began in February after a former student killed 17 people at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla.

TailParas.Para: Hundreds of related events are planned across the U.S. and abroad this weekend, from Jonesboro, Ark., to Anchorage, Alaska, and as far away as Japan and Australia.
But for some participants, there is no substitute for the nation's capital, even if it means traveling overnight on buses or flying inconvenient routes to keep costs down.

They move in big groups and small and hail from across the U.S., not only large cities and wealthy suburbs but also places more sympathetic to arguments for gun rights. A bus of 56 set off from Beloit, Wis., this week, while 18 students from Louisville, Ky., piled into their chaperones' cars. A student activist and her mother are making the trip from outside Salt Lake City.

"Congress is [in Washington], and it will hit home if all of us showed up where these politicians are, and protested even in the cold," said Ariel Lopez, an 18-year-old senior from Jacksonville, Fla. Mr. Lopez worked overtime at his job at a local Starbucks on Wednesday and found friends to cover his weekend shifts so he could attend the rally.

His group of six, all from Englewood High School in Jacksonville, were unsuccessful in raising money from a GoFundMe campaign, so they bought the cheapest tickets they could find—with a layover in Charlotte, N.C. To get home, they are taking a bus from Washington to New York and then flying to Jacksonville, via Atlanta.
"It is intense, but it is worth it for us because it is a great cause," Mr. Lopez said.
Last week an estimated 1 million students walked out of schools across the U.S. in 17-minute protests against government inaction on gun control.
Many hope the momentum will continue to build.
"This is our place to jump in and not take no for an answer," said Isabella Bryson, a 16-year-old junior at Lakewood High School, a Cleveland suburb, who helped organize a bus trip to Washington.

Ms. Bryson and two friends were inspired by how many students from their high school participated in the recent walkout. They made posters and fliers and hung them at school. Although school administrators quickly pulled them down, students took photos and shared them on social media, they said.

"We found that a really large number of students wanted to be part of it," said Sara Pepe, a co-organizer with Ms. Bryson. "We were worried that we couldn't meet the bus minimum, but now we have a waiting list."
Some activists face opposition from students who abhor school violence but also cherish the right to bear arms and reject efforts to curtail it.

Han Johnson, a senior in a conservative part of northern Utah, said she's unable to gin up support in her own high school. So she travels for more than two hours to Salt Lake City and back each week to meet with students planning a march there.
"People at my school just seem to think it is a joke," she said. "I've gotten a lot of negative feedback, especially on the march. People think we're trying to take away their guns."

Pro-gun rallies, which have billed themselves as marches in defense of the second amendment, have been scheduled at the same time as Saturday's "March for Our Lives" rallies. A group called Defend the Second Amendment is holding rallies in cities including Los Angeles and Boston, which organizers say is against "bans on so-called assault rifles."

An overwhelming majority of the rallies, though, are expected to be in support of gun control. For the rally in Washington, many students have had their trips sponsored or facilitated by strangers, who have opened up their homes, funded their travel or provided food, ponchos, bullhorns and other essentials.

Ms. Bryson and her team were able to raise $6,000 through a GoFundMe campaign to cover the costs of renting a bus. Mr. Lopez and his friends found accommodation through March for Our Lives Lodging, a group that brought together 1,600 Washington residents who were willing to open their homes to students.

Elizabeth Andrews, a Washington-based tax lawyer and mother who founded the lodging group, had to close the lodging submissions page this week after reaching capacity. Her group is helping marchers in other ways too: planning potluck dinners, picking them up from the airport and serving as Washington guides.

Among the youngest participants is 11-year-old Mackenzie Lewis. The sixth-grade resident of Columbus, Ohio, had her trip sponsored by RISE Travel, an advocacy group that has brought activists from Ohio to Washington for a range of marches and protests. Without the sponsorship, her mother said, she wouldn't have been able to make the trip.
"It just isn't fair that a child would go to school and be shot," Mackenzie said. "I'm very serious about this cause—I will do whatever it takes for kids to not get shot."
Write to Shibani Mahtani at shibani.mahtani@wsj.com
